Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Resolving Turbulence-Chemistry Interaction Using Novel Laser Diagnostics

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0844939
Ma

Understanding turbulence is one of the great challenges of physical science; understanding the complicated interactions of turbulence and chemistry is scientifically even more challenging, but it is also ubiquitous in engineering devices and processes. A sound understanding of turbulence-chemistry interaction (TCI) can lead to fundamental improvements in such devices and processes, contributing to the solution of societal issues such as energy security and global warming. Mastering it calls for innovative methods that can resolve the underlying physics to a new level. This project proposes new experimental techniques to address both the science and applications in fundamental and applied systems.

The concept is to characterize both the turbulence and the chemistry, especially in two-phase flows, by using photodissociation (PD) to create photofragments that can be measured optically. Precursor molecules are seeded in the gaseous or two-phase flow of interest, then photodissociated by a laser pulse. Because of the nanosecond rapidity of the dissociation, a view of the flow is captured and the TCI can be temporally resolved. Because the dissociation is complete, the resulting photofragment represents the distribution of the seeded precursor. Imaging the concentration of this photofragment can then generate multidimensional measurements of key flow parameters like mixture fraction, scalar dissipation rate, and rates of reaction, which are critical to TCI but generally not measurable with existing experimental methods. This project attempts to develop a unified diagnostic for two-phase flows based on PD, in the sense that the diagnostic characterizes both phases based on the same tracer and sensing technique (even the same lasers and cameras) to elucidate the rich interactions in two-phase flows. Extensive collaborations will be established to share and disseminate the experimental results.

Success in this challenging project will have significant impact technologically, but it also has the potential for a significant impact educationally through integration into a range of educational activities. The ultimate aim of this project is to develop these techniques for wide use through collaboration, disseminating data, and teaching its concepts in the classroom and the laboratory. The experimental research will be useful in reforming traditional lecture-based courses, using physical and virtual laboratories to deliver interactive learning opportunities that can also be extended beyond college classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Turbulence-chemistry interaction (TCI) represents a key process governing the operation of a wide range of power devices, ranging from furnaces to gas turbine engines. However, our current understanding of TCI remains far from complete, and the design of more efficient and cleaner power devices suffers from such incomplete understanding. A key hurdle to a better understanding of TCI is the experimental difficulty of measuring key properties involved in TCI. Such difficulty is compounded by the nature of turbulent flows, whose structures are inherently three-dimensional (3D) and temporally transient. Therefore, it has been long desired to have experimental techniques that can resolve TCI processes with sufficient spatial resolution, temporal response, and dimensionality.

Thus, the goal of this project is to study TCI using novel laser diagnostics. Several new diagnostics were proposed and demonstrated to overcome the limitations of existing techniques or to complement their capabilities. These new diagnostics are demonstrated to resolve TCI processes in a 2D plane or 3D volume, enabling new methods and data for model validation and development. For example, a new technique developed in this project utilizes photodissociation spectroscopy (PDS) to image mixture fraction, a most pivotal quantity for TCI, in 2D.  The PDS technique relies on the photodissociation of a precursor seeded in the target flow. The precursor molecules are then completely photodissociated by a nanosecond laser pulse to produce photofragments, which are subsequently imaged and used to calculate mixture fraction. The nanosecond rapidity of the photodissociation ensures the temporal response, and the completeness ensures the distribution of the resulting photofragment the same as the seeded precursor. Hence, imaging the distribution of this photofragment can then generate multidimensional measurements of mixture fraction, which subsequently yields other important flow and flame properties such as scalar dissipation rate and rates of reaction, parameters critical to TCI but generally not measurable with existing experimental methods. As a second example, another technique was developed to enable instantaneous 3D measurements by combining tomography with laser spectroscopy. The concept is to expand a laser pulse to illuminate the 3D target flow volumetrically, instead of focusing a laser pulse to illuminate the target at a plane or along a line as typically practiced in the past.  Then signal is generated volumetrically and is captured simultaneously by several cameras from multiple orientations. Signal on each camera provides partial information of the 3D target from its perspective, and a tomography algorithm was developed to combine all the partial information provided by all the cameras to generate a complete measurement of the target in 3D. This concept has been demonstrated in two-phase flows by combining scattering spectroscopy with tomography, and in combustion flows by combining emission and fluorescence spectroscopy with tomography.

The intellectual merit of this work stems from both the fundamental scientific significance of TCI and also its ubiquitous application in a wide range of practical devices. The experimental capabilities available to resolve TCI are limited in various ways such as spatiotemporal resolution, dimensionality, and types and regimes of flames applicable. The experimental tools developed in this project are expected to overcome these limitations and to provide new capabilities long desired. These new capabilities have been demonstrated to enable measurements of properties critical to TCI, such as mixture fraction, dissipation rate, 3D flame surface area, 3D flame volume, and 3D curvature. These new capabilities are expected to play an active role in the study of TCI and contribute to a better fundamental understanding of turbulent combustion.
